33. But Phocion, whom one could call good-natured,
looked so severe because of his eyebrows
that no-one would come speak to him
easily and without flinching,
unless they had known him already.
When the people of Athens laughed
at his eyebrows, (he said) “They offend no one,
but such empty laughter costs this City many tears.”

34. Yet it may well be that he also overcame
his own inclinations (like a Philosopher),
and did not let them to be moved so quickly
by his irascible nature, but instead
acted against what Physiognomy taught;
though anyone turning to Trogus on this subject,
to Adamantus, or Aristotle,
will be easily bored by lengthy, strange noise.

35. We have no wish to tire ourselves
with the arguments of the Philosophers,
but let them float away,
as things which do not decide for us.
But we must consider the motion of the Body’s exterior,
The change and movements of its limbs,
for the benefit to our art, so that anyone might easily see
what our Figures endure or accomplish.

36. They are not wrong, those who reproach us
for so poorly distinguishing
between laughter and tears in our faces;
but as we study from life, we see
that in laughter the mouth and cheeks widen
and lift, the brow flattens, and between the two,
the eyes are half-closed and squeezed,
making small creases toward the ears.
left-middlePainters cannot easily distinguish between a laughing and crying face.

37. But weeping faces are not so round,
the cheeks are narrower;
the lower lip, and corners of the mouth
droop downward. In ancient times
some understood these things well;
one might mention Praxiteles,
the great Master working especially in marble,
creating Art which was the wonder of the World.
